quotes.quote: Keep on radar bleeding edge technologies vs sunset technologies
Follow job market requirements
Understand business
Be the Worst in the team so you can learn from others
Learn/know different type programming languages (C#, C, python, prolog…)
Avoid fear-driven career choice
Keep on radar known tech/platforms vs unknown(to learn)
Learn what is under abstraction layer of your programming language
Use different technologies
Log your excitement level over days
Everyday learn something new about tech/tools you are using
Learn how business work
Have/find a mentor
Be a Mentor
Practice (Google Code Jam, Project Euler, Code Katas)
Know/learn Software Development Methodologies
Read other’s code (and criticize it)
Automate tasks
Do it now!
Predict the future – possible requested features (make it easy to implement it)
Make daily review (problems, processes to improve)
Understand your manager/company goals
Set goals for you current job (long term)
Make boring tasks fun!
How much are you worth?
Share you areas of knowledge in job (implemented modules, deployment process etc.). Make documentation
Measure (by metrics), improve, measure
Work as hard as you can (no fb, twitter etc.)
Learn how to fail
Say ‘No’ when you know you cannot do something
Don’t panic
Say It, Do It, Show It
Be aware what others think about you (managers, team mates etc.)
Don’t make people afraid of you
Track you decisions and analyze them (diary)
In person communication over email/Skype
Have elevator pitch (business benefits of your recent work)
Have the mission!
Be present on-line (blog, twitter, LinkedIn)
Care about your brand (google yourself)
Contribute to open source!
Be remarkable (do something what will take a week in one day)
Propose changes/features to software you are using (mail author)
Be up to date with current/new tech
Try to do your job as you are your manager
Path is more important than destination
Create map of your past, current and future career (and what your learn, when you lost time)
Try to be alpha geek (or follow some of them)
Ask your coworkers for feedback
Avoid monkey traps (do not be too confident in some things, or review them from time to time; know your enemy – play with technology you don’t like)
Avoid Waterfall career planning
Be better every day
Try to go independent (e.g. 2 hours/day after work hours) – how much did you earn?
